title: $A higher as Chinese shares recover
text:
Wed, Aug 19, 2015, 5:50 PM AEST - Australia Markets closed $A higher as Chinese shares recover AAP – 15 minutes ago Print 
The Australian dollar has followed the wild ride taken by China's sharemarkets, falling around lunch time before staging a late recovery. 
At 1700 AEST on Wednesday, the currency was trading at 73.53 US cents, up from 73.47 cents on Tuesday, and the low of 73.14 US cents it hit just after 1300 AEST. 
Westpac senior currency strategist Sean Callow said the Aussie had mimicked the heavy losses on Chinese equity markets throughout the day. 
Shanghai shares plunged more than five per cent in the middle of the day, before bouncing in the final hour of trade. 
"The Aussie dollar has traded off a lead from Chinese stocks, which has been reinforced by some weakness in iron ore prices," Mr Callow said. 
"Chinese financial markets have generated some big swings today, particularly on the downside, but now we are heading into the London morning in better spirits." 
The Shanghai Composite plunged more than six per cent on Tuesday on worries the Chinese government will pare back support for the faltering stockmarket. 
At 1700 AEST, the Australian dollar was at 91.37 Japanese yen, unchanged from Tuesday's close, and at 66.45 euro cents, up from 66.35 euro cents. 
The Australian bond market is unchanged as enthusiasm mounts for a US rate hike and amid China's sharemarket volatility. 
Nomura rate strategist Andrew Ticehurst said it was an extremely quiet and low volume session on Wednesday, with traders watching Chinese equities in the absence of local news. 
Mr Ticehurst said the Australian market rallied gently in response to pain from Shanghai shares on Tuesday. 
"General nervousness about the health of the Chinese economy and stockmarket is also providing support today," he said. 
Wednesday night's US inflation data for July and the Federal Reserve's minutes due early Thursday morning will be on the radars of most global investors. 
The minutes, which are the last official communication before the September interest rate decision, could signal whether the Fed is likely to raise interest rates for the first time in nine years. 
"The market will try to glean clues from the language about whether it's September versus December," Mr Ticehurst said. 
"At the moment it seems like a coin toss and the market's priced 50/50." 
At 1630 AEST on Wednesday, the September 2015 10-year bond futures contract was trading at 97.225 (implying a yield of 2.775 per cent), unchanged from Tuesday. 
The September 2015 three-year bond futures contract was at 98.060 (1.940 per cent), unchanged. @y7finance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook Reject Shop says profit growth will return AAP
